steps.name: notes
value: For working with internal modules, LivePerson is using Reggie

steps.name: p
steps.value: Reggie is a NodeJS server which is a lightweight alternative to a full blown npm registry

steps.name: notes
value: As for today, there is no simple out of the box solution for managing a private NPM repository
Doing it, still requires managing a full replication of the public repository
There is a proxy solution (Kappa) from PayPal that we still need to check, but currently we are using Reggie which is a very simple solution
Lets see what we have inside - via postman

steps.name: notes
value: Formally, We started working with Node in LivePerson, almost a year ago

value.name: li
value.value: Two Server Applications in GA (Loggos & Batchelor)

value.name: li
value.value: Many More Expected Node Projects in Queue

steps.name: notes
value: Available Modules: lp_js_gate_keeper, lp_js_http_status, lp_js_localcache, lp_js_logger, lp_js_service_status, lp_js_security_utils, lp_js_service_directory
Go to Reggie and talk a little about existing modules
We've Created the Integration and Services LivePerson Uses Like Cassandra, Service Directory, etc. Rapidly, without the need to use the company java implementations
I would like to ask Efim to talk a little about LivePerson Modules and our vision

steps.name: notes
value: There comes a time during our application development phase, that we would like to understand its limits

value.name: li
value.value: Understanding the maximum load our application can handle

value.name: li
value.value: Learning where our Node program spends its time

value.name: li
value.value: Making sure our application is dealing with basic load without "melting"

value.name: notes
value: Lets talk about creating load

steps.name: notes
value: Important to remember when testing locally

steps.name: p
steps.value: Use loadtest or tools like nodeload for local stress testing

steps.name: notes
value: Before we'll deal with distributed stress testing, Lets start with local tests
Lets see the loadtest module
But this is not enough for understanding the real numbers our application supports
For that we will need to conduct distributed stress testing
